rev.diff:
Line 27: Line 27:
Mubarak dissolved his government and appointed military figure and former head of the [[Egyptian General Intelligence Directorate]] [[Omar Suleiman]] as Vice-President in an attempt to quell dissent. Mubarak asked aviation minister and former chief of Egypt's Air Force, [[Ahmed Shafik]], to form a new government. Opposition to the Mubarak regime has coalesced around [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], with all major opposition groups supporting his role as a negotiator for some form of transitional unity government.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Shadid|first=Anthony and David D. Kirpatrick|title=Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/31/world/middleeast/31-egypt.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=30 January 2011}}</ref> In response to mounting pressure Mubarak announced he would not seek re-election in September.<ref>{{Cite news|author=El Deeb, Sarah; Al-Shalchi, Hadeel|title=Egypt Crowds Unmoved by Mubarak's Vow Not To Run|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=12815050|accessdate=1 February 2011|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[ABC News]]'')|date=1 February 2011}}</ref>
Mubarak dissolved his government and appointed military figure and former head of the [[Egyptian General Intelligence Directorate]] [[Omar Suleiman]] as Vice-President in an attempt to quell dissent. Mubarak asked aviation minister and former chief of Egypt's Air Force, [[Ahmed Shafik]], to form a new government. Opposition to the Mubarak regime has coalesced around [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], with all major opposition groups supporting his role as a negotiator for some form of transitional unity government.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Shadid|first=Anthony and David D. Kirpatrick|title=Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/31/world/middleeast/31-egypt.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=30 January 2011}}</ref> In response to mounting pressure Mubarak announced he would not seek re-election in September.<ref>{{Cite news|author=El Deeb, Sarah; Al-Shalchi, Hadeel|title=Egypt Crowds Unmoved by Mubarak's Vow Not To Run|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=12815050|accessdate=1 February 2011|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[ABC News]]'')|date=1 February 2011}}</ref>
â
==Background==
 
{{Politics of Egypt}}
{{Politics of Egypt}}
  +
==Background==
  +
Since the 1981 assassination of President [[Anwar El Sadat]], [[Hosni Mubarak]] has headed Egypt's [[Semi-presidential system|semi-presidential]] republic government and is the longest serving President in Egypt's history. Mubarak and his [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party (NDP)]] government have maintained one-party rule under a continuous state of emergency.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak">{{cite web|author=|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|title=Hosni Mubarak|work=The New York Times |date=8 March 2010|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mubarak's government earned the "support of the West and a continuation of hefty annual aid from the United States" by maintaining policies of heavy handedness towards Islamic militants and peace with Israel.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak" />
Since the 1981 assassination of President [[Anwar El Sadat]], [[Hosni Mubarak]] has headed Egypt's [[Semi-presidential system|semi-presidential]] republic government and is the longest serving President in Egypt's history. Mubarak and his [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party (NDP)]] government have maintained one-party rule under a continuous state of emergency.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak">{{cite web|author=|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|title=Hosni Mubarak|work=The New York Times |date=8 March 2010|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mubarak's government earned the "support of the West and a continuation of hefty annual aid from the United States" by maintaining policies of heavy handedness towards Islamic militants and peace with Israel.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak" />
Line 56: Line 57:
===Economic climate===
===Economic climate===
{{Main|Economy of Egypt}}
{{Main|Economy of Egypt}}
â
[[File:Flickr - Daveness 98 - Cairo neighborhood.jpg|thumb|A neighborhood in Cairo]]
 
Egypt's economy was highly centralized during the rule of former President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] but opened up considerably under former President Anwar Sadat and current President Hosni Mubarak. Cairo from 2004 to 2008 aggressively pursued economic reforms to attract foreign investment and facilitate GDP growth, but postponed further economic reforms because of global economic turmoil. The international [[economic downturn]] slowed Egypt's GDP growth to 4.5 percent in 2009. In 2010, analysts assessed the government of Prime Minister [[Ahmed Nazif]] would need to restart economic reforms to attract foreign investment, boost growth, and improve economic conditions for the broader population. Despite high levels of economic growth over the past few years, living conditions for the average Egyptian remained poor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|title=Egypt Economy 2010|source=[[CIA World Factbook]]|date=27 January 2010|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
Egypt's economy was highly centralized during the rule of former President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] but opened up considerably under former President Anwar Sadat and current President Hosni Mubarak. Cairo from 2004 to 2008 aggressively pursued economic reforms to attract foreign investment and facilitate GDP growth, but postponed further economic reforms because of global economic turmoil. The international [[economic downturn]] slowed Egypt's GDP growth to 4.5 percent in 2009. In 2010, analysts assessed the government of Prime Minister [[Ahmed Nazif]] would need to restart economic reforms to attract foreign investment, boost growth, and improve economic conditions for the broader population. Despite high levels of economic growth over the past few years, living conditions for the average Egyptian remained poor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|title=Egypt Economy 2010|source=[[CIA World Factbook]]|date=27 January 2010|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
Line 73: Line 73:
===Population growth===
===Population growth===
{{main|Demographics of Egypt}}
{{main|Demographics of Egypt}}
  +
[[File:Flickr - Daveness 98 - Cairo neighborhood.jpg|thumb|A neighborhood in Cairo]]
The population was 30,083,419 in 1966,<ref name="ReferenceOxford Atlas">The British Oxford economic atlas of the World 4th edition, ISBN 019 8941072</ref> which has now grown to roughly 79,000,000 people by 2008.<ref name=popclock>{{cite web|url=http://www.msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg/pls/fdl/tst12e?action=&lname=|title=Central Agency for Population Mobilisation and Statistics â Population Clock (July 2008)|publisher=Msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg|date=|accessdate=25 August 2010}}</ref> Most Egyptians live near the banks of the [[Nile]] River, in an area of about {{convert|40000|km2|sp=us}}, where the only [[arable land]] is found. The emerging [[overpopulation]] crisis thus led to poverty, hygiene, education, and housing issues, as well as a lack of adequate arable land.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tulane.edu/~rouxbee/kids98/egypt3.html|title=Overpopulation in Egypt: Too Many People, Too Little Space and Resources|publisher=Tulane.edu|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
The population was 30,083,419 in 1966,<ref name="ReferenceOxford Atlas">The British Oxford economic atlas of the World 4th edition, ISBN 019 8941072</ref> which has now grown to roughly 79,000,000 people by 2008.<ref name=popclock>{{cite web|url=http://www.msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg/pls/fdl/tst12e?action=&lname=|title=Central Agency for Population Mobilisation and Statistics â Population Clock (July 2008)|publisher=Msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg|date=|accessdate=25 August 2010}}</ref> Most Egyptians live near the banks of the [[Nile]] River, in an area of about {{convert|40000|km2|sp=us}}, where the only [[arable land]] is found. The emerging [[overpopulation]] crisis thus led to poverty, hygiene, education, and housing issues, as well as a lack of adequate arable land.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tulane.edu/~rouxbee/kids98/egypt3.html|title=Overpopulation in Egypt: Too Many People, Too Little Space and Resources|publisher=Tulane.edu|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
